pageContent._comments: object that contains data for page labels, buttons, etc.

_common.name: App Connect for Manufacturing - Integration with the IBM Operational Decision Manager (ODM) using the Java Compute node
_common.shortDescription: Create one simple message flow by using the OPC-UA-Read node and Java Compute node to connect to an ODM Server. This tutorial requires an installation of App Connect for Manufacturing and set up of the IBM Operational Decision Manager. This tutorial assumes you are familiar with the creation of Rules in the Rules Designer and deploying the Rules on the Rules Execution Server.
_common._resourceToOpenComment: The ID of the first resource to open when the user imports the tutorial. Resource IDs are defined in the repo_metadata.json.

pageDetails._topicListComment: A short list of product concepts or tasks demonstrated by this tutorial

topicList.title: Creating and deploying rules on ODM Rules Server
Creating and starting an Integration Server
Creating secure vault to store ODM credentials
Configuring the OPC-UA-Read node message flow and integrating with the Java Compute node.

pageDetails._outcomesComment: Learn how to create one simple message flow by using the OPC-UA-Read node and Java Compute node to connect to an ODM Server.

outcomeList.title: Learn how to create one simple message flow by using the OPC-UA-Read node and Java Compute node to connect to an ODM Server.

summary._overviewComment: This tutorial demonstrates how to create one simple message flow by using the OPC-UA-Read node and Java Compute node to connect to an ODM Server.

sections.section: This tutorial assumes you have installed and configured IBM Operational Decision Manager(ODM) and that you are familiar with Rules development and deployment on the Rules Server. For more information, see Installing IBM ODM in the help links provided below.
This tutorial assumes you have installed and configured App Connect for Manufacturing. For more information, see Installing IBM App Connect for Manufacturing in the help links provided below.
You must create an integration server before you can deploy integration solutions and related resources. You will also need to connect your Toolkit to an OPC server.

You can try out this message flow by simply importing the three provided projects. One application project contains a control flow and another application project contains a read flow using the OPC-UA-Read and Java Compute node.The third project is a Policy project.
The tutorial will guide you through deploying and starting both flows.

The read flow is driven using its HTTP Input node, which triggers the flow to run. The OPC-UA-Read node then reads data from the connected OPC server. Next, the Java Compute node is invoked for the execution of the Decision Rules. The response from the message flow is then returned to the HTTP client by the HTTP Reply node.

sections.section: Click Import and the App_OPCUA_ODM_JCN , App_OPCUA_Control and Policy_OPCUA_ODM_Project applications will be imported into your workspace.
The Policy_OPCUA_ODM_Project project contains an ODM policy that specifies the parameters to connect to the ODM Rules Server.

overview.name: Prepare
overview.heading: Prepare for the flow using ODM Rules node
overview._prepareComment: Prepare for flow using ODM Rules node

details.details: This section assumes you have installed and configured IBM Operational Decision Manager. It also assumes knowledge and understanding of creating rules project, specifying XOM object, creating BOM from XOM, defining the rule operation , specifying rules using action rule / Decision Table etc., and finally the deployment of the rule set.
For further information on Rules, please refer to https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/odm/8.11.1?topic=8111-decision-server-rules
In the sample example, we create XOM using the Java definition in 'SimpleAirConditionerObject.jar' which is located under the APP_OPCUA_ODM_JCN --> Other Resources, under the Application Development.
In this example, we have specified the 'temperature' and 'humidity' as input values and the outcome of the Decision Rule is expected in the 'status' parameter.
For more details on the creating XOM and BOM  please refer to https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/odmoc?topic=model-overview-dynamic-execution-object-xom
Import the sample SimpleAirConditionerObject.jar in the Rules project --> Import XOM  , using the Rules Designer.
Create BOM from the XOM created in the above step.
Add the Decision Operation. Add a new Variable set and specify the input output parameters for the rule set.

In our sample example, we need to specify the ACObject as Input-Output parameter. This implies that the object that we pass as parameter to the ODM Rules Java API will contain the output result as well.

Create the rule using option such as Action Rule or Decision Table. For example, rule in the Decision table could return Status of the ACObject as 'ALARM' if the temperature is greater than a certain value.
Finally, deploy the Rule Set on the Rules Execution server.

sections.section: Creating a Data Source connection to an OPC Server

details.details: To create a data source, complete the following steps.
Ensure that your OPC UA server is up and running.
In the IBM App Connect Enterprise Toolkit, navigate to the Manufacturing Perspective > DataSources.
Right-click the Source folder and select Add Mapping Node.
Specify a name for the mapping node and click OK. The new data source gets created under the DataSource Properties window.
Select Server URL Type as Endpoint
Specify your OPC Server URL: For example: opc.tcp://TEST_OPC_SERVER:port/OPCUA/SimulationServer
Keep the default values for the remaining data source properties and click Create DataSource
Check the data source activity in the Logging view for any issues.
On successful connection of a data source, App Connect for Manufacturing allows you to create Client Item and map it to the available source item from the OPC server.

Assuming you are using a Windows platform, open an App Connect Enterprise Command Console and start an integration server using the following command:
IntegrationServer --work-dir C:\TESTSERVER --name TESTSERVER --admin-rest-api 7600 --http-port-number 7800 --console-log
where C:\TESTSERVER is a folder on your file system that the server will use for its working directory.
Navigate to the folder where the server.conf yaml file is located.

For example : Modify C:\TESTSERVER\server.conf.yaml in windows and /opt/TESTSERVER/server.conf.yaml in linux/unix to add the following lines under 'ConnectorProviders' to add App Connect for Manufacturing connector provider properties.:

For Windows:
  ACMfg:
    connectorClassName: 'com.ibm.industrypack.industryclient.connector.ICConnectorFactory'
    jarsURL: 'C:\Program Files\IBM\ACMfg\3.0.1.0\runtime\amd64_nt_4'
    property1: 'trustCertificate=true'
    property2: 'allowEndpointMismatch=true;discardData=false'

For Linux/Unix:
  ACMfg:
    connectorClassName: 'com.ibm.industrypack.industryclient.connector.ICConnectorFactory'
    jarsURL: '/opt/IBM/ACMfg-3.0.1.0/runtime/amd64_linux_2'
    property1: 'trustCertificate=true'
    property2: 'allowEndpointMismatch=true;discardData=false'
Note: The jarsURL is the installation directory of App Connect for Manufacturing that points to the amd64_nt_n folder.
Save the above server.conf.yaml file and restart the Integration server using the command mentioned in step 1

In the App Connect Enterprise Toolkit Integration Explorer view, right click the folder and select the menu item . In the connection details panel, specify the Host name to be localhost, the Port to be 7600 and click Finish. This will connect your Toolkit and display the integration server that you started in the last step

sections.section: Creating secure vault using mqsicredentials for the Integration Server

details.details: For the integration server created in the above section, we need to create a secure vault and add the credentials of the ODM Rules Server.For example, in the below command secure vault with vault key testODMVault1 is created. Credential Type is odm.Specify any credential-name and appropriate username and password to connect to the ODM Rules Server.
mqsicredentials --work-dir C:\TESTSERVER --vault-key testODMVault1 --create --credential-type odm --credential-name odmCred --username user --password pass
Restart the Integration server by specifying the vault-key created above.

Assuming you are using a Windows platform, open an App Connect Enterprise Command Console and start an integration server using the following command:
IntegrationServer --work-dir C:\TESTSERVER --name TESTSERVER --admin-rest-api 7600 --http-port-number 7800 --console-log --vault-key testODMVault1
where C:\TESTSERVER is a folder on your file system that the server will use for its working directory.
Create a Policy Project with a Policy of type 'ODM Server' and Template as 'ODM Server'. Sample Policy project is provided with the tutorial and will be imported along with the other applications.
Please provide the required parameters for the Policy project as described in https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/app-connect/11.0.0?topic=properties-odm-server-policy-odmserver
Rule Execution Server URL specifies the URL of the Rules Execution Server. For example,http://localhost:9080/res/

ODM Jars URL specifies the file location of the IBM ODM Execution Server Client Jar files to be used by the policy. For example: C:\IBM\ODM\executionserver\lib. You will need to copy the jars from the ODM Execution server to the machine that is running the Integration Server and specify the folder location accordingly.

secureIdentity specifies the secure identity containing the credentials to be used for accessing the Rule Execution Server. In our sample example, credential name is odmCred as described in the section Creating secure vault using mqsicredentials for the Integration Server
Rest of the properties can be selected as default.

overview.name: Run
overview.heading: Configure, Deploy and Test the Read Flow using the ODMRules node
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

sections.section: Configure the ODM Rules Message flow

details.details: From the Application Development view, under the App_OPCUA_ODM_JCN application, double-click Flow_OPCUA_ODM_JCN.msgflow to open in the Flow Exerciser.
Navigate to the Flow Exerciser and double-click the OPC-UA-Read node to open the OPC-UA-Read Node properties.
From the node properties window, click 'Add' to open the Manufacturing perspective.
Select the appropriate 'Data source' that was created earlier in the Prepare section.
Click on 'Refresh Source Item Tree' to load the Source Items. Select the node from the source tree for which you want to read data
From the 'Client Items' tree, right-click on the 'Item' node and select 'Add Mapping Node'
Specify a name for the node and click 'Ok'
Click 'Create Client Item' from the 'Client Item Properties' tab
Click 'Add Client Item to Read'. The client item is added to the Selected Client Items panel in the 'Select' view.
In our example project, /Item/AC1_temperature and /Item/AC1_humidity are the two client items corresponding to the Temperature and Humidity of an AirConditioner system.
These client item names are referenced in the Java Compute Node. You will need to update the Java Compute node in case the client items have names other than the ones mentioned above.
From the OPC-UA-Read node, select the Input Message Parsing and select the Message domain as 'XMLNSC : For XML messages (namespace aware, validation, low memory use)'
Double-click the Java Compute node. This will load the auto-generated code along with the code for our sample example.
The function setup
The function evaluate
Alternately, instead of using the sample example, you can add a new Java Compute Node. The next steps describe how you can add a new Java Compute node and select the required ruleset.

i) Add a new Java Compute node from the Pallete.
   ii) Double-click the new Java Compute node. The Java Compute node class window loads.
    iii) Select the default values and click 'Next'.
iii) From the JavaCompute node class template window, select 'Process via Operational Decision Manager ruleset'.
iv) Specify the required parameters to connect to the ODM Server and click 'Next'.
v) If the connection is successful, the window 'Select a ruleset for the Java ODM Template' loads.
vi) Select the appropriate Rules application, Rule application version, Ruleset, Ruleset version.
vii) The appropriate ruleset parameters are then loaded.
viii) The appropriate ruleset parameters are then loaded.
ix) Please make sure to check the option for 'Download the jar files assosicated with this ruleset jars and add them to the Java project.
x) Click 'Next' and select the default values in the Java Settings window.
x) Click 'Next' and click on 'Finish' to complete the set up of the Java Compute node.
xi) The above steps will auto-generate the code for the above Java Compute node and it will also download the Java XOM API jar under the APP_OPCUA_ODM_JCN --> Other Resources folder.

xii) In the auto-generated code, you will need to add code to read from the OPC-UA-Read node and populate the object to be passed to the Rules server. Please refer to our sample code provided in the original Java Compute node provided with the example flow.
Connect the OPC-UA-Read node to the one of the above Java Compute nodes (either the sample Java Compute node or the new Java Compute node created above).
Save the flow

For details on connecting to the ODM Server using Java Compute node, please refer to the Knowledge Center Link: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/app-connect/12.0?topic=uodmobr-executing-odm-business-rules-by-using-javacompute-node
Ensure that you are connected to the Integration Server
From the Application Development view, under the App_OPCUA_Control application right-click the Flow_OPCUA_Control.msgflow and select 'Deploy'.
In the Deploy window, select the Integration Server that you have started, and Click 'Finish'.
Click 'Ok' to confirm the deployment. The control flow application name is displayed under the selected integration server from the Integration Nodes view.

sections.section: Deploying the Policy project and ODM Rules node message flow

details.details: Ensure that you are connected to an Integration Server.
From the Application Development view , right-click the Policy project for ODM server policy created earlier, and select 'Deploy'.
From the Application Development view , right-click the Flow_OPCUA_ODM.msgflow and select 'Deploy'.
In the Deploy window, select the integration server that you have started, and click Finish.
Click 'Ok' to confirm the deployment.The App_OPCUA_ODM , App_OPCUA_Control and Policy_OPCUA_ODM_Project are displayed under the selected integration server from Integration Nodes view.

sections.section: Testing the Flow_OPCUA_ODM Flow using the Flow Exerciser

details.details: Ensure that your Integration Server is started.
Navigate to the Flow Exerciser of the Flow_OPCUA_ODM.msgflow.
In the editor, click the Start Flow Exerciser icon in red: to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.

You can right-click on 'InputMessage' to add a new message and then click on 'Send' button. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node. After the request message is processed, the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow.
Click on any connection on the message box to see the data that passed through that connection.
Click on the link between first Compute node and the ODM Rules node to view the Input Ruleset parameter object ACObject in the LocalEnvironment tree.
Click on the link between ODM Rules node and the second Compute node to view the returned 'Status' in the Ruleset parameter object ACObject in the LocalEnvironment tree.
To stop recording the message path through the flow, click the 'Return flow to edit mode' icon.
